doc.title: Freenet, VOD, UK fibre war, Iliad/ Salt results
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/Freenet VOD UK fibre war IliadSalt resultsFreenet VOD UK fibre war IliadSalt results_2025-08-28

passages.text: We highlight latest research, news flow and significant observations relevant to our stock coverage across European/ CEEMEA Telecoms, and Global Towers/Satellites.

- Telco conference 2 and 3 September 
- Please see below link for registration details

- Freenet 
- Slower growth, re-acceleration needed in 2H

- Vodafone 
- Another activist investor builds stake

- Openreach (BT) 
- Calls for softer Ofcom regulation in competitive UK areas

- Iliad 2Q25 (Not Covered) 
- Group's EBITDA/OpFCF growth accelerates, further slow down in France, solid in Italy

- Salt 2Q25 (Not Covered) 
- Improved financial performance with sustained subscriber growth

Registration is now open for our Media and Telecom Forum taking place virtually on 2 and 3 September. The forum will offer the opportunity to attend virtual meetings and fireside chats with senior management from a wide range of global media and telecom companies. Please see the link for registration details.

Post 2Q25 results, we update our estimates. We decrease our FY25E/FY26E revenues by \(- 0.5\% / - 0.3\%\) and Adj. EBITDA by \(- 0.7\% / - 0.7\%\) , respectively, reflecting higher mobile ARPU erosion and lower Waipu TV net adds. This leaves us at the low end of the company's Adj. EBITDA guidance for 2025E (€520m- 540m). We decrease our FY25 FCF estimate by \(- 3.5\%\) , at the low end of guidance (€300m- 320m). We increase our FY26 estimate by \(+3.1\%\) . As a result, we raise our DCF- based price target from €33.5 to €34.0/share, leaving upside potential of \(+20\%\) . Our estimates, Freenet trades at 8.6x FY25E EV/EBITDA, 9.4x EV/OpFCF and offers an \(8.3\%\) ECFF yield. This compares to its peer group at 7.8x, 11.2x, and \(8.3\%\) . We remain EW (new PT
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 5. Completed: 28- Aug- 25, 07:06 GMT Released: 28- Aug- 25, 07:07 GMT Restricted - External
European Telecom Services
€34.0 PT vs €33.5 PT). A potential upside risk is German consolidation as discussed in Consolidation 2.0 - Sizing the RanCo opportunity - 26 June 2025.

Press reports suggest that Martin Ebner, a Swiss investor, has taken a \(3\%\) stake in Vodafone through his investment vehicle Patinex. The article labels Mr Ebner as a "feared activist investor". Although the article makes no mention of his intentions for Vodafone, the article suggests he has not aggressively pushed for changes, and has taken a less hands on approach in some of his recent investments. We note that Vodafone has a history of attracting activist investors - In the past few years, Cevian Capital, Elliott, Xavier Niel, Liberty Global and E& have historically taken material stakes in Vodafone, often making calls for strategic change, typically with limited impact, although we note that Vodafone did pivot its M&A strategy and changed leadership 2- 3 years ago, selling Spain and Italy in an attempt to reposition the strategy. Liberty Global has recently disposed of its Vodafone stake. Source: Telegraph (27 August 2025)

Openreach calls on Ofcom to relax rules in areas with three or more FTTP providers or Virgin Media presence. Ofcom's current framework classifies \(90\%\) of the UK as partially competitive (Area 2), with no zones yet deemed fully competitive (Area 1). Openreach argues that sustained restrictions risk undermining Openreach's 2030 target of 30m FTTP premises, especially as rivals covered \(42.26\%\) of the UK by 1H25. Altnets, however, argue that competition is still in the process of being established, and some are unhappy about the revised definitions for Area 2 and 3. Ofcom's final Telecoms Access Review 2026 proposals are expected imminently, with market consolidation and viability still uncertain. See our research UK Fibre wars - AltNet pressure to build in 2025; downgrade BT to UW (10 March 2025), for latest trends in UK broadband market. Source: ISPreview (27 August 2025)

Group revenues grew \(+3.3\%\) yoy organically driven by service revenue growth of \(+3.0\%\) yoy (vs. \(+5.7\%\) yoy in 1Q25). EBITDA algrew organically by \(+14\%\) yoy \((+6\%)\) in 1Q25) whilst Capex was down \(- 4\%\) yoy enabling a \(+30\%\) growth of OpFC. Leverage stands at 2.3x (vs 2.7x at YE2024). We note a continued slow down in France with service revenues up only \(+0.9\%\) yoy \((+4\%)\) in 1Q25) as volume growth stalled (no Mobile/Broadband growth). In Italy service revenue growth remains solid at \(+9.4\%\) yoy (in line with 1Q25). Mobile volumes remained steady with \(+287k\) mobile net adds (vs \(+218k\) in 4Q25) and 32k Broadband net adds (vs \(+40k\) in 1Q25).

Salt Operating Revenue improved \(+4.6\%\) y/y to CHF 251.2m, driven by continued postpaid mobile and broadband subscriber growth and supported by the price adjustment implemented in March. EBITDA increased by \(+4.0\%\) y/y to CHF 149.5m, with an EBITDA margin standing at \(52.4\%\) (2Q24: \(52.1\%\) ). With total cash investments of CHF 83.7m (2Q24: CHF64.7m), Free Cash Flow amounted to CHF 36.8m (2Q24: CHF 45.6m). Salt fibre footprint now reaches 2.5m households, representing around \(50\%\) of all households in Switzerland. By the end of 2025, the number is expected to be approaching three million. Source: Company (28 August 2025)

Sky Switzerland is launching its new connectivity services Sky Fiber and Sky Mobile for the whole of Switzerland based on Salt's fiber and mobile networks. Sky fibre offers 2.5Gbps speed for CHF35 per month and 5G mobile offers unlimited calls/SMS and data (5G) starting at CHF17.95 per month in combination with a Sky Show or Sky Sport subscription. Without Sky Show or Sport Pass the tariffs cost CHF55 and CHF22.95 respectively. Source: Company (26 August 2025)

In back to school promotion Bouygues is lowering its triple play offer price. Initially offered at €28.99 per month for the first year and then €35.99, the Bbox Rentrée is now billed at €26.99 for the first year and then €33.99. The offer includes 1Gbps fibre, as well as a package of TV services. It is positioned as an intermediate alternative between the B&You Pure Fibre TV- free package (€23.99/month, no commitment) and the more high- end offers in the Bouygues catalogue. Competition remains intense in the French market. Source: Universfreebox (27 August 2025)

Deutsche Telekom Germany - Adds 240k new fibre homes passed in JulyDeutsche Telekom added more than 240k new fibre homes passed in July, reaching a total fibre footprint of around 11.3m households. As we detail in our research German broadband in focus with latest BNETZA data in focus (23 May 2025) the German regulator has published data for 2024 that points a clear slowdown in the broadband market net adds, with steady AltNet momentum causing losses for established players. However Deutsche Telekom continues to grow Broadband revenues thanks to upsell of existing Broadband customers on higher speeds and richer offers. Source: Company (26 August 2025)

Lyse (not covered) reported a \(+34\%\) yoy growth in 1H25 telecoms revenue to NOK 6.18bn, with EBITDA up \(+73\%\) to NOK 2.50bn. EBIT surged \(+409\%\) to NOK 1.05bn, driven by a NOK 794m oneoff gain from restructuring Bergen Fiber/Eviny Fiber. Adjusted from that one- off item, adjusted EBIT stood at NOK 252m. Capex reached NOK 1.64bn in 1H25, up NOK 181m yoy. Lyse added \(+15k\) fibre customers on its own infrastructure, totalling 597k, while its Altbox partnership gained \(+25k\) , reaching 932k (incl. 58k in Denmark). Ice grew its mobile base by 37k in 1H25 to c1.02m and completed its national roaming switch to Telenor. Interestingly, Lyse Tele reports a "ketchup effect" on its mobile base station numbers adding 1k in 1H25, totalling 4.5k. See
Scandi deep dive – Growth intact with fixed accelerating (13 June 2025), for recent trends in Norway market. Source: Telecompaper, Efficient (27 August 2025)

SpaceX's Starlink (not covered), has successfully tested a new "mini laser" in orbit, enabling its satellites to link with third- party satellites and space stations. The system supports speeds of 25Gbps over distances up to 4,000km, targeting platforms in low and medium Earth orbits. Starlink's existing inter- satellite links (ISLs) operate at up to 200Gbps but are limited to internal connections. Starlink currently operates c.8,190 satellites, with thousands more planned by end- 2027. The new laser could open additional revenue streams via external satellite connectivity. Source: ISPreview (27 August 2025)

China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology has released a strategic roadmap to accelerate satellite communications, aiming for over 10m users by 2030. The plan outlines regulatory reform, infrastructure upgrades, and expanded market access, including mobile- to- satellite connectivity and low- orbit satellite internet. It supports commercial trials for satellite IoT and encourages private sector participation through resource sharing and value- added services. Emergency response, rural coverage, and industrial applications are prioritised to broaden use cases. The initiative also promotes international cooperation and standardisation to strengthen China's global position in satellite communications. Source: China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (25 August 2025)

We, Ganesha Nagesha, Mathieu Robilliard and Maurice Patrick, hereby certify (1) that the views expressed in this research report accurately reflect our personal views about any or all of the subject securities or issuers referred to in this research report and (2) no part of our compensation was, is or will be directly or indirectly related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this research report.

Deutsche Telekom AG (DTEGn.DE, 27- Aug- 2025, EUR 31.70), Overweight/Neutral, A/CD/D/E/J/K/L/M/N
Freenet (FNTGn.DE, 27- Aug- 2025, EUR 28.62), Equal Weight/Neutral, FA/J

Unless otherwise indicated, prices are sourced from Bloomberg and reflect the closing price in the relevant trading market, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
GE: One of the Research Analysts on the fundamental equity coverage team (and/or a member of his or her household) has a long position in the common equity securities of this issuer.
H: This issuer beneficially owns more than \(5\%\) of any class of common equity securities of Barclays PLC.

P: A partner, director or officer of Barclays Capital Canada Inc. has, during the preceding 12 months, provided services to the subject company for remuneration, other than normal course investment advisory or trade execution services.
R: Barclays Capital Canada Inc. has received compensation for investment banking services from this issuer in the past 12 months.
S: This issuer is a Corporate Broker to Barclays PLC.
U: The equity securities of this Canadian issuer include subordinate voting restricted shares.
V: The equity securities of this Canadian issuer include non- voting restricted shares.
Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.
Below is the list of companies that constitute the "industry coverage universe":

Elisa Oyj (ELISA.HE) INWIT (INWT.MI) Liberty Global (LBTYA) OTE (OTEr.AT) Swisscom (SCMN.S) Telecom Italia-RSP (TLIT.NI) Telia Company AB (TELIA.ST) Vodafone Group Plc (VOD.L)

Stock Rating: UNDERWEIGHTIndustry View: NEUTRALClosing Price: GBp 216 (27-Aug-2025)

Source: IDC, Barclays Research
Link to Barclays Live for interactive charting
On 28-Aug-2022, prior to any intra- day change that may have been published, the rating for this security was Overweight, and the adjusted price target was 2.40.
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
\*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.
Valuation Methodology: We value BT based on a SOTP and DCF methodology, with a \(6 - 8\%\) WACC and \(0 - 1\%\) terminal growth rate

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Upside risks include scope for M&A market repair - in part Vod/3UK, but also likely AltNet consolidation. Downside risks include a growing materialization of overbuild risks determining whether BT has greater pricing power in wholesale FTTH (and correspondingly lower Retail ARPU risk). Changing bond yields can impact BT's pension deficit.
Stock Rating: OVERWEIGHT  Industry View: NEUTRAL  Closing Price: EUR 31.70 (27-Aug-2025)
Rating and Price Target Chart - EUR (as of 27-Aug-2025)  Currency=EUR
Source: IDC, Barclays Research  Link to Barclays Live for interactive charting
On 28-Aug-2022, prior to any intra-day change that may have been published, the rating for this security was Overweight, and the adjusted price target was 23.50.
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.
**Valuation Methodology:** We use a DCF-based SOTP with WACCs ranging from 6.5-10% and terminal growth ranging from +1-2%.

**Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target:** Downside risks include a deterioration in the competitive environment in the US and in Germany, value destructive deals and a deterioration of macro conditions notably in Germany. Upside risks include faster growth in the US, competitive trends in Germany improving and better-than-expected macro conditions.
Stock Rating: EQUAL WEIGHTIndustry View: NEUTRALClosing Price: EUR 28.62 (27-Aug-2025)

Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
\*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.
Valuation Methodology: We value Freenet using a DCF and SOTP methodology. We use a WACC of \(7.25\%\) and terminal growth rate of \(1\%\) .

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Upside risks to our estimates include better volume growth in mobile and IPTV and German mobile consolidation. Lower- than- expected take up of TV, more competition on mobile are downside risks.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate-friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

Any information, data, image, or other content including from a third party source contained, referred to herein or used for whatsoever purpose by Barclays or a third party ("Information"), in relation to any actual or potential 'ESG', 'sustainable' or equivalent objective, issue, factor or consideration is not intended to be relied upon for ESG or sustainability classification, regulatory regime or industry initiative purposes ("ESG Regimes"), unless otherwise stated. Nothing in these materials, including any images included therein, is intended to convey, suggest or indicate that Barclays considers or represents any product, service, person or body mentioned in these materials as meeting or qualifying for any ESG or sustainability classification, label or similar standards that may exist under ESG Regimes. Barclays has not conducted any assessment of compliance with ESG Regimes. Parties are reminded to make their own assessments for these purposes.
